Introduction

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection (eg, tympanic membrane bulging, marked erythema).  OME is most commonly seen in children, often following an episode of acute otitis media (AOM); however, it may also occur in adults, typically in association with eustachian tube dysfunction.

Pathogenesis



A middle ear effusion occurs when serous or mucoid fluid accumulates in the middle ear space.  This commonly occurs after an episode of AOM (even when the infection is treated) (

figure 1
).  The buildup of fluid within the middle ear exerts pressure on the tympanic membrane, reducing its ability to vibrate and transmit sound to the ossicles.  The resultant conductive hearing loss is typically mild and transient, resolving within a few weeks as the effusion resorbs.



Effusions that persist >3 months can become increasingly viscous due to the accumulation of mucins and proteins.  This increases the risk for prolonged hearing impairment and may contribute to speech and language delays, particularly in young children during critical developmental periods.



The pathogenesis of persistent middle ear effusion is not fully understood, but 2 main factors are believed to contribute:



  • Eustachian tube dysfunction (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  The eustachian tube plays a critical role in ventilating the middle ear and draining secretions into the nasopharynx.  When its function is impaired (eg, due to inflammation or anatomic abnormalities) drainage becomes inadequate.  In addition, failure of the eustachian tube to open properly creates negative pressure within the middle ear, which causes a transudative effusion (eg, clear, amber, or yellow fluid).
  • Chronic middle ear inflammation:  Residual bacterial components or biofilm formation following an episode of AOM can impair mucociliary clearance and promote persistent inflammation and mucus secretion within the middle ear.

Risk factors



The risk factors for developing OME are similar to those for AOM:



  • Age <2:  Children age 6-12 months are at the highest risk, likely due to the eustachian tube being shorter and more horizontal in young children, which hinders fluid drainage (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Formula-feeding:  Breastfeeding is protective against AOM and OME, likely due to the relative decrease in bacterial colonization of the nasopharynx and/or the immunologic benefits of breastmilk.
  • Day care attendance:  Increases the incidence of upper respiratory infections and may also increase the risk for exposure to biofilm-creating bacteria.
  • Passive smoke exposure:  Appears to increase colonization of the nasopharynx with otopathogens and promotes eustachian tube dysfunction.
  • Anatomic abnormalities:  Conditions including cleft palate, craniofacial syndromes, Down syndrome, adenoid hypertrophy, and nasopharyngeal masses are associated with eustachian tube dysfunction.

Clinical presentation



The predominant manifestation of symptomatic OME is conductive hearing loss, although the presentation varies somewhat between adults and children.  Adults typically report subjective hearing loss and ear fullness, whereas most children are asymptomatic (or may not verbalize hearing changes).



In young children, speech and language delays may be the primary indicators of hearing loss from OME.  Parents should be specifically asked about developmental issues because these symptoms often go unrecognized.  Caregivers may also observe subtle behavioral changes, such as decreased attentiveness or a preference for higher volumes on electronic devices.

Differential diagnosis



  • AOM (
    figure 3
    ):  Characterized by the sudden onset of ear pain and fever, typically accompanied by a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane on otoscopy examination.
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction:  Can lead to ear fullness and muffled hearing but without a middle ear effusion on otoscopy.
  • Cholesteatoma (
    figure 4
    ):  Most commonly presents with painless, recurrent otorrhea; conductive hearing loss is usually present.  Otoscopy shows keratin debris, usually emanating from a retraction pocket in the superior portion of the tympanic membrane.

Diagnosis



OME is diagnosed on examination by the presence of a middle ear effusion in the absence of acute infection.  Key otoscopic findings include:



  • A dull and retracted tympanic membrane.
  • Immobility of the tympanic membrane on pneumatic otoscopy.
  • Visible fluid behind the tympanic membrane, which appears as an air fluid level, bubbles, or an amber-colored effusion (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Landmarks including the ossicles and/or the light reflex are often obscured.

Evaluation

Audiologic evaluation



Audiologic testing (eg, audiometry, tympanometry) can help confirm the diagnosis of OME when otoscopic findings are inconclusive.  In addition, audiometric evaluation is recommended in the following circumstances:



  • Persistent middle ear effusion for >3 months.
  • Middle ear effusion associated with subjective hearing loss.
  • Child with middle ear effusion who exhibits signs of speech and language delay or has risk factors for developmental delay.


Audiometry is a diagnostic test that measures hearing ability across a range of sound frequencies and intensities.  It helps identify the type, degree, and configuration of hearing loss.  Audiometry in OME typically reveals conductive hearing loss, especially at lower frequencies, as fluid in the middle ear reduces tympanic membrane mobility.



Tympanometry provides objective information about the mobility of the tympanic membrane and the pressure within the middle ear, both of which are affected by the presence of fluid.  Compared to a normal tympanogram (

figure 6
), a tympanogram in OME is flat because the effusion restricts tympanic membrane and ossicular chain mobility (
figure 7
).  Tympanometry can be used to confirm the presence of an effusion and monitor resolution over time.

Laboratory testing and imaging studies



Patients diagnosed with OME typically do not require further laboratory testing or imaging because the condition is usually self-limited.  However, imaging studies may be indicated in certain cases.  For example, nasopharyngoscopy is recommended for adults with recurrent, unilateral OME (especially in the absence of a preceding episode of AOM) to assess for eustachian tube obstruction due to a nasopharyngeal mass.  CT scan of temporal bones is indicated when there is concern for cholesteatoma, a benign growth of squamous epithelium in the middle ear that can complicate OME.

Management



OME often resolves spontaneously; therefore, watchful waiting for 3 months after diagnosis is appropriate in patients with mild or no hearing loss and without risk factors for speech, language, or developmental delays.  In contrast, patients with significant hearing deficits or high-risk features should undergo otolaryngology evaluation.



Tympanostomy tube placement is the mainstay of treatment for effusions that cause significant symptoms (eg, moderate to severe hearing loss, ongoing ear fullness, developmental delays).  Most effusions that persist for >3 months will also require tube placement.  Tympanostomy tubes are inserted into the tympanic membrane to ventilate and drain the middle ear, bypassing the eustachian tube (

figure 8
).  They typically extrude spontaneously within 6-12 months.

Complications



The primary complication of OME is conductive hearing loss and speech/language delays.  Without intervention, communication difficulties can persist long after OME resolution due to deficits in normal auditory processing and neural pathway development.

Prognosis



The prognosis for OME is generally very favorable.  Long-term outcomes in children who receive appropriate treatment, including tympanostomy tubes, are generally excellent, with hearing returning to normal after resolution of the effusion.

Summary



Otitis media with effusion is defined by the presence of noninfected fluid in the middle ear, most often after an episode of acute otitis media.  Although many patients are asymptomatic, the fluid can impair sound transmission across the tympanic membrane, leading to conductive hearing loss.  In young children, this may contribute to speech and language delays.  Diagnosis is typically made via otoscopy, which reveals a dull, immobile tympanic membrane and evidence of middle ear effusion.  Most cases resolve spontaneously, but tympanostomy tube placement is indicated for persistent effusions and those associated with hearing loss or developmental concerns.
